docs.lead_paragraph: "We were concerned about the appearance of conflict of interest," a spokesman for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said about the agency's recently appointed 16-member scientific panel on smoking. It's hard to tell that from the makeup of the panel. The board of outside scientists is supposed to assure the accuracy and fairness of two yet-unpublished studies conducted by the agency on the health effects of secondhand cigarette smoke. And yet six members, including the chairman, Dr. Morton Lippmann of New York University, have ties, some stronger than others, to a research group financed by Philip Morris Companies , the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and Lorillard Inc. , three of the largest tobacco companies. A seventh member was appointed at the urging of Philip Morris. The tobacco industry's influence was also reflected in the treatment of another member, Dr. David Burns of the University of California. Dr. Burns wrote the Surgeon General's report on passive smoking and is widely considered a leading expert on the issue. He was dismissed from the research panel in response to complaints from the tobacco industry, and reinstated only after the dismissal was publicly disclosed. If the Environmental Protection Agency is really concerned about the credibility of its findings on smoking, there's a clear path: Reconstitute the panel now.

byline.original: BY JOYCE JOHNSON; Joyce Johnson is the author of a memoir, "Minor Characters," and a novel, "In the Night Cafe."

docs.lead_paragraph: THE ROAD WE ARE ON NOW," our guide Nikolai announces dryly to the busload of American writers and their spouses, "was once called the Boulevard of the Enthusiasts." It picked up that name in the 19th century when political prisoners were herded along it in chains for the long walk to Siberia. Fortunately, we're now headed in the opposite direction, back to Moscow and the seedy comforts of the Hotel Ukraine, after our day trip to the ancient city of Suzdal and its innumerable wooden churches. At this point, the jet-lagged passengers reserve their enthusiasm for supper and bed. We arrived just yesterday for our conference with the Soviet Writers' Union, now going through its own glasnost. Since 9 A.M., we have spent nine hours in this lurching un-air-conditioned vehicle. The poet Sharon Olds has given away all the trail mix she brought with her from Manhattan, where she also stuffed her suitcase with tuna fish. Unfortunately, the cans are in her room.

headline.main: Anger in Youth Linked To Future Heart Attack

docs.lead_paragraph: Hostile teen-agers are likely to grow up to be adults who have high cholesterol levels, according to a study that finds new links between anger and heart trouble. For years, many experts assumed that hard-driving, impatient people, type A personalities, were at high risk of suffering heart attacks. But many have grown skeptical of this theory, and some now believe that the truly lethal personality trait is hostility and anger.
